item.title: Imprint
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Responsible for Twick.it are:

Markus Möller and Sean A. Kollak Hohler Weg 1, 57072 Siegen, Germany info |at| twick.it The webmasters are not liable for any contents linked or referred to from this page. The webmasters of the linked sites are liable for their content exclusively.

Data protection

This website uses Google Analytics, a web analytics service provided by Google, Inc. ("Google"). Google Analytics uses "cookies", which are text files placed on your computer, to help the website analyze how users use this site. The information generated by the cookie about your use of the website (including your IP address) will be transmitted to and stored by Google on servers in the United States. Google will use this information for the purpose of evaluating your use of the website, compiling reports on website activity for website operators and providing other services relating to website activity and internet usage. Google may also transfer this information to third parties where required to do so by law, or where such third parties process the information on Google's behalf. Google will not associate your IP address with any other data held by Google. You may refuse the use of cookies by selecting the appropriate settings on your browser, however please note that if you do this you may not be able to use the full functionality this site. By using this website, you consent to the processing of data about you by Google in the manner and for the purposes set out above.

Use of Facebook social plugins

Our website uses social plugins (“plugins”) provided by the social network facebook.com, operated by Facebook Inc., 1601 S. California Avenue, Palo Alto, CA 94304, USA (“Facebook”). The plugins are identifiable by a Facebook logo (white letter f on blue background or a thumb up icon) or the notice “Facebook Social Plugin”. For a full list of all social Plugins please see http://developers.facebook.com/plugins. When you visit a page of our website that contains a social plugin, your browser establishes a direct connection to Facebook servers. Facebook directly transfers the plugin content to your browser which embeds the latter into the website, enabling Facebook to receive information about your having accessed the respective page of our website. Thus we have no influence on the data gathered by the plugin and inform you according to our state of knowledge: The embedded plugins provide Facebook with the information that you have accessed the corresponding page of our website. If you are logged into Facebook, your visit can be assigned to your Facebook account. If you interact with the plugins, for example by clicking “Like”, or entering a comment, the corresponding information is transmitted from your browser directly to Facebook and stored by it. Even if you are not logged into Facebook, there is possibility that the plugins transmits your IP-address to Facebook. For the information on the purpose and scope of data collection and procession by Facebook, as well as your rights in this respect and settings options for protecting your privacy please visit Facebook’s privacy policy: http://www.facebook.com/policy.php. If you are a Facebook member and do not want Facebook to connect the data concerning your visit to our website with your member data already stored by Facebook, please log off Facebook before entering our website. Further you can block Facebook social Plugins by using add-ons for your browser, like the “ Facebook Blocker“.

item.title: Charter
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
We – the users of Twick.it – have a common aim: To create an explain engine which everybody can join and everybody can use. To achieve this aim we observe the following rules which make cooperation in a big community easier.

We support Twick.it.

Twick.it lives on our knowledge and engagement – our explanations, valuations, reporting of misuse, of our constructive criticism, recommendation and new applications. Only through our support the explain engine can deliver good results over a long period of time.

We respect laws.

We accept the terms of Twick.it and respect existing laws and conventions.

We stick to facts.

Even though we know that knowledge and opinion can not always be separated clearly we stay factual when formulating a Twick.

We are fair.

We don’t want to insult, discriminate or slander anybody.

We don’t lie.

We want to avoid spreading half-truths, propaganda, ideologies and lies

We valuate explanations – not people.

We rate a Twick considering its content not our personal relationship to the author.

We respect the opinion of individuals.

We believe that differing explanations may enrich a knowledge data base. Therefore we accept the opinions of other users.

We respect the wisdom and verdict of the many.

All users vote together to detect which Twick explains a topic best.

We make mistakes – and learn from them.

To err is human. Therefore we make an effort to write Twicks with the necessary accuracy. We accept that people make mistakes and are open for criticism and suggestions for improvement.

We don’t manipulate.

We do not use automated routines to manipulate Twick.it and do not try to access unauthorised data (see terms).

We are having fun!

We enjoy our engagement in Twick.it as our cooperation is informative, productive and entertaining. We learn something while we use Twick.it and spread the knowledge gained.

item.title: FAQ
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
General questions

What is Twick.it? What is a Twick? Does a Twick belong to anybody? How can I support Twick.it? Are you the new Wikipedia? Is Twick.it an Italian company?

Questions concerning registration

Can I valuate Twicks without being logged in? Can I create several accounts? Which information should I present in my profile? What do I have to consider when creating my username? My username is already being used. What can I do? I have forgotten my password. What can I do? After registration I have not received an e-mail with the link of approval. What now?

Questions concerning handling

Can other users see who has given a valuation? Can I explain a topic several times? Can I valuate a Twick several times? Can I change my valuation of a Twick? Has Twick.it got criteria of relevance? How can I add a Twick to my favorites and remove it from my favorites? Which links are allowed? I am very unhappy with a certain Twick. What can I do? Which behaviour can lead to a blocking of my account?

Questions concerning functions

How do you determine the most popular Twick? Why do I have to confirm my Twick twice? How is the tag-cloud created? Why are some topics typed wrongly? How can I change my picture?

General questions

What is Twick.it?

  • Twick.it is an explain engine. Here you find short explanations for topics written and valuated by users. An explanation is also called Twick.
  • By analysing keywords Twick.it can display semantic connections between topics and explanations (tag-cloud, topic tree and related topics).
  • Concept and code of Twick.it has been developed by Markus Möller and Sean Kollak.
  • When registering every user accepts the Twick.it general terms and conditions (AGB).
You find more information about the concept of Twick.it in our blog. At the moment most articles are available in German only. We will translate them as soon as possible.

What is a Twick?

  • Explanation of a topic in 140 characters or less.
  • A link which offers additional information may be added.
  • A Twick can and should be valuated by other users.
  • A Twick can be edited by its author until it has a positive valuation sum (bigger than 0). This allows improving Twicks which are not formulated well or contain typing errors. When reaching a positive valuation sum a Twick can no longer be edited – otherwise it would lose its original meaning.
To receive as many positive valuations as possible your Twick should be intelligible, precise, up-to-date and entertaining. In our blog category Tips4Twicks we present tips for twicking (currently only in German).

Does a Twick belong to anybody?

Just as well you could ask: To whom does speech and knowledge belong? Twicks are User Generated Explanations of topics, formulated for all users with the idea in mind to create a general encyclopaedia of human knowledge.
  • Knowledge and speech belong to all humans as they are created in the act of communication, by sharing. The same applies for Twicks.
  • The author of a Twick is honoured through his gravatar and individual information he can present in his profile.
  • When entering a Twick in the Twick.it database users confirm the acceptance of our general terms and conditions (AGB).

How can I support Twick.it?

Every serious act improves the quality of Twick.it! So:
  • Write good Twicks
  • Valuate Twicks
  • Report misuse
  • Comment and develop our ideas in the blog
  • Tell your friends
  • Bookmark topics and Twicks
  • Create new applications with our API
  • Use the Twick.it widgets

Are you the new Wikipedia?

No. Twick.it is not a competitor but a supplement to the online-encyclopaedia Wikipedia. There are important differences between Wikipedia and Twick.it:
  • In Wikipedia many authors are working on one article. This leads to Editor War. In Twick.it everybody can write his own explanation of a topic. The users alone (not administrators) decide on the best possible explanation.
  • Short and sweet: That is the principle of Twick.it. The diversity of explanations offers a quick and up-to-date overview of relevant information concerning a certain topic. Wikipedia on the other hand offers very detailed information.

Is Twick.it an Italian company?

  • No. Twick.it is a project of Markus Möller and Sean Kollak. Both are German.
  • The domain Twick.it is located in Italy. By using the domain .it we want to motivate users to join in actively, to write and valuate explanations.

Questions concerning registration

Can I valuate Twicks without being registered?

  • No. Only if users are registered we can make sure that they do not manipulate Twick.it by valuating Twicks several times.

Can I create several accounts?

  • Yes. You can create an account with every valid e-mail-address.
  • CAUTION! Users who create several accounts and systematically valuate a certain group of Twicks will be blocked.

Which information should I present in my profile?

  • When registering a Twick.it account only your username and e-mail-address are required. This allows us to associate a Twick with its author and prevent spam. All other information in your profile is optional.
  • For your username you can use your real name or create an artist name.
  • CAUTION! It is forbidden to Twick in a name which harms personal rights of another person.

What do I have to consider when creating a username?

  • The username must not contain an @-sign or empty space, it must not start with punctuation marks and is limited to 255 characters at the most.
  • If you want to twick anonymously you should create a fictional username.
  • CAUTION! You are not allowed to use a name of a real person such as “Bill Gates” or “John F. Kennedy” if this is not your real name. It harms personal rights and is illegal.

My username is already being used. What can I do?

  • Nothing. First come, first serve. A name such as “Markus Möller“ is not unique. Whoever registers the name first may use it for twicking.
  • EXEPTION! If you can prove that a person illegally twicks using your name please contact the Twick.it administrators. The account will be deleted and the username can be used for a new registration.

I have forgotten my password. What can I do?

  1. Click on “Forgot password“
  2. Enter your username and e-mail-address
  3. You receive an e-mail with a link of approval
  4. Click on the approval-link
  5. Your receive an e-mail with a new password which you can change
This process ensures that only you can reset your password.

After registration I have not received an e-mail with the link of approval. What now?

Please make sure first that the registration mail has not landed in your junk mail. If you have not received it:
  • Click on “Send registration mail again”
  • Enter your username or e-mail-address. We suggest using the e-mail-address so you can make sure that you have not made a mistake when registering originally.
  • The registration mail with the link of approval will be sent to you again.

Questions concerning handling

Can other users see who has given a valuation?

  • No. Whether positive or negative valuation: No user can see who judged a Twick.
  • This anonymity will prevent discussions as well as mutual positive or negative valuation.

Can I explain a topic several times?

  • Yes. But you may only write 2 Twicks about a certain topic within 24 hours.

Can I valuate a Twick several times?

  • No. You can valuate a Twick only once.
  • CAUTION! Users who create several accounts and systematically valuate a certain group of Twicks will be blocked.

Can I change my valuation of a Twick?

  • Yes. New and better explanations are being made constantly and your opinion concerning a topic might change over time. Therefore you can change your valuation of a Twick any time – as often as you like.

Has Twick.it got criteria of relevance?

Yes. But only the users decide what is relevant. Every topic of general interest that does not oppose laws or the Twick.it terms (AGB) may be explained. Topics and Twicks which no user shows interest in will be deleted automatically from the databank according to these simple rules:
  • If a Twick does not receive one positive valuation within 12 months it will be deleted automatically.
  • If a topic does not receive a second Twick within 12 months it will be deleted automatically.
Twick.it reserves the right to modify these criteria of relevance with increasing numbers of users.

How can I add a Twick to my favorites and remove it from my favorites?

  • If you like a Twick click on the star symbol. Immediately the Twick will show up in your favorites.
  • If you do not like a Twick anymore click on the star symbol again. The Twick will be removed from your favorites automatically.

Which links are allowed?

  • Basically you can link any website, blog or URL. The linked source should contain relevant information to the topic you explained.
  • CAUTION! If you misuse the link function Twick.it reserves the right to block your account.
  • Please do not use short-URLs as users cannot see where the link leads to. Short-URLs are not forbidden but not wanted either.

I am very unhappy with a certain Twick. What can I do?

Since it is so easy to use Twick.it it will be subject to spam, nonsense and misuse. We are dependent on your help to give bad explanations a negative valuation and report misuse.
  • Twicks which you don’t like but describe the chosen topic should be given the thumbs-down. They will vanish into insignificance.
  • Twicks which do not belong into an encyclopaedia can be reported as misuse. Click on the skull symbol and chose a category. Every user can report a single Twick as misuse once. If the Twick is reported as misuse by several users it will be deleted from the databank automatically. Twick.it reserves the right to block accounts of users who repeatedly misuse the website.
Before reporting misuse you should consider that everybody is entitled to share his knowledge. The diversity of explanations is important to Twick.it.

Which behaviour can lead to a blocking of my account?

  • If you create several accounts to systematically valuate a certain group of Twicks.
  • If you behave totally destructive – for example you give only negative valuations without formulating your own explanations.
  • If your choice of words is vulgar, discriminating or racist.
  • If you insult people.
  • If you twick in the name of a real person which you are not.
  • If the content of your Twicks or links is illegal or pornographic.
  • If you twick spam or inappropriate advertising.
  • If your link always lead to irrelevant sources.
  • If you spread lies in your Twicks.
  • If you automat or manipulate Twicks or valuations.

Questions concerning functions

How do you determine the most popular Twick?

  • The most popular Twick is the one with the best relation of positive to negative valuations. This Twick will be listed at the top in subsequent queries.
  • Actuality beats age: If two Twicks have the same valuation sum the one that has been added more recently will be displayed higher in the ranking.

Why do I have to confirm my Twick twice?

  • Before you enter a Twick into our databank you should reread it to avoid mistakes and errors. This improves the quality of Twick.it for all users and prevents the need for later editing.
  • Moreover the second confirmation offers a good protection against automatically generated spam mails.

How is the tag-cloud created?

  • The tag-cloud displays the 10 words which are used most often when describing a certain topic.
  • A set of fillers, swearwords and punctuation marks are filtered from the tag cloud.
  • Words which are repeated in a Twick are only counted once.
  • If a user has written several Twicks to explain a topic only the one with the better valuation sum will be analyzed for the tag-cloud.

Why are some topics typed wrongly?

  • The user who first explains a topic decides whether it is written in capital letters or not.
  • Additionally a spell check is committed when a new topic is being explained. It automatically defines whether a certain topic is written in capital letters or not.
Nevertheless mistakes can occur when explaining a new topic.

How can I change my picture?

The pictures next to the Twicks are gravatars. Twick.it automatically checks if you have a gravatar for your e-mail-address or the Twitter-account which you have stated when registering.
  • You can create a gravatar at www.gravatar.com for every valid e-mail-address. Depending on which e-mail you use to twick the appropriate gravatar will be displayed next to your Twick.
  • Alternatively if you are already using Twitter and stated your Twitter-account in your profile your Twitter-gravatar will be displayed.

item.title: Concept
item.dc:creator: sean
item.content:encoded:
Twick.it is an explain engine – which everybody can join.

The aim of Twick.it is to find the best explanation for every topic in every language. Whatever you are looking for: At Twick.it you find a wealth of topics explained by people. You can valuate these explanations, formulate your own explanation, add new topics and report misuse. Using Twick.it is child’s play and fun, too. The only difficulty is: Your explanation must not be longer than 140 characters! As everybody can join Twick.it. there are many differing explanations. The exiting question is: Who can explain a certain topic best? Go for it! Only you are responsible for your Twick – nobody else can edit it. But everybody can valuate it. The better your explanation is valued by others the higher it will be listed in subsequent queries. In addition to your explanation you can fill in abbreviations and add a link to an internet source which offers more information. The more, the better: With every sensible explanation and valuation the explain engine is improved! A semantic analysis detects related topics as well as the most import keywords (see Tag-Cloud and Topic Tree). This let’s you explore areas of topics. It’s quick, it’s easy and it’s fun.

Explanations for everybody

The explanations collected in Twick.it can be used by everybody! A few examples: You can display explanations of a certain topic area automatically in your blog. Or you mark a word on your website – as soon as somebody explained it at Twick.it it will be displayed as tool-tip on your website. Or you may use Twick.it to find people who are interested in the same topics as you. If you are tired of checking the endless Gooooooooogle search results you can use the Twick.it-search instead. It can be installed in every browser quickly and easily. These are only a few of our ideas – more applications will follow. To makes this happen we have installed a connection (API) for programmers. And with every new application it becomes even more attractive to join Twick.it. What are you waiting for? If you have any questions regarding registration or use of Twick.it your will find an answer in our FAQs.

item.title: REST-API
item.dc:creator: markus
item.content:encoded:
Are you a developer and do you like to create your own cool applications based on Twick.it? With our programming interface this is no longer a problem. You can use many Twick.it functions with our API. This is a so called REST-API which means, that all functions are called by a HTTP request. That request returns data als XML or JSON. With this technic is does not matter which programming language you use or on what kind of device your application should run. The only think you have to be sure of is that you can send a HTTP-Request and handle the returned data. All URLs are located under http://twick.it/interfaces/api and return the results encoded as UTF-8. We will explain the API calls in detail on separate sites:
  • explain - Retrieves the explanation of a topic.
  • favorites - Retrieves the favorite Twicks of an user.
  • find_topic_by_tag - Retrieves all topics with a specific search term in their tag clouds.
  • find_topic - Retrieves a topic.
  • find_topics_nearby - Retrieves all topics that are located nearby a position.
  • find_twick - Retrieves a Twick with a specific ID.
  • find_twicks_from_user - Retrieves all Twicks written by a specific user.
  • find_user - Retrives detail information about an user.
  • latest_twicks - Retrieve the latest Twicks.
  • random_twick - Retrieve random Twicks.
  • random_topic - Retrieve random topics.
  • search_twick - Retrieves all Twicks which includes a given search term.
Important news and changes regarding the API are published at our Twitter account @twickit_api.
<li><strong><a href="/blog/fur-entwickler/api/find_topics_nearby/">find_topics_nearby</a></strong> -  Liefert alle Thema, die sich in der Nähe einer Position befinden.</li>

item.title: explain
item.dc:creator: markus
item.content:encoded:
URL:

http://twick.it/interfaces/api/explain.xml http://twick.it/interfaces/api/explain.json

Function:

Retrieves the explanation of a topic by returning the best Twick(s).

Parameters:

optional/required Values Default Description
search required String Name of the topic
limit optional Integer 1 Number of Twicks. A number less or equal 0 means no limitation.
similar optional Boolean 1 or 0 0 Also search for similar topic titles if 1 is specified as parameter value. Otherwise the title must exactly match the search term.
skipHomonyms optional Boolean 1 or 0 0 Do not show [twickit word="Homonym"]homonyms[/twickit] (=ambiguous meanings) if 1 is specified as parameter value.
lng optional "de", "en" preferred browser language Language in with the topic should be explained

Output(XML):

http://twick.it/interfaces/api/explain.xml?search=Fliege 
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<result>

item.title: Terms
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
General terms and conditions (AGB) Twick.it – the explain engine

1. Licence and rights of use

All explanations presented in Twick.it are subject to the Creative-Commons Attribution (CC-BY). According to CC-BY further use of the content is permitted as long as the author is mentioned. Both GDFL as well as CC-BY permit the commercial use of content.

2. Accountability

Twick.it users are responsible for their explanations. This includes external links set by usera. The webmasters of Twick.it do not ssume liability for external links. Twick.it users commit themselves to respect international laws. Twick.it users respect the rules for productive cooperation which are formulated in the Twick.it Charter.

3. Prohibitions

It is forbidden to twick illegal content. It is forbidden to twick in the real name of another person (whether living of dead). It is forbidden to use Twick.it in combination with tools of automation. Especially automated registering of accounts, automated formulation of Twicks and automated valuation are forbidden. It is allowed to access data using the Twick.it API. It is forbidden to hack or skip security routines and access other users’ data.

4. Blocking and deletion of accounts

Illegal, pornographic, vulgar and insulting content will be deleted irrevocably from the database by the webmasters as soon as they are informed about such. Twick.it reserves the right to block accounts if a user does not follow the general terms and conditions (AGB).

Exclusion of liability

5. Content of the website

The webmasters assume no warranty regarding actuality, correctness, completeness or quality of the published information. Claims against the webmasters which relate to material or immaterial damage due to the use or disuse of the published information or the use of incomplete or wrong information are excluded categorical, as long as the webmaster can not be proved purposeful wrong or very negligent behaviour. All content and applications are subject to change and without obligation. The webmasters explicitly reserve the right to change, supplement or delete contents or even the whole website without prior notice.

6. Pointers and links

Direct or indirect links to external internet content which are outside the area of responsibility of the webmasters would lead to a liability only in the case if the webmasters are informed of the content and it is technical possible and reasonable to stop the usage of illegal content. The author of a Twick confirms that the linked website was free of illegal content at the time of adding the link. The author has no influence on the momentary and future design and content of the linked websites. The author distances himself explicitly from all contents of the linked websites which have changed since the time of adding the link. Liable for illegal, misleading or incomplete contents and damages which occur by the use or disuse of such information is only the person responsible for the website which has been linked, not the person who has directed to the respective content.

7. Disclaimer

The content of Twicks not necessarily reflects the opinion of the webmasters. Twicks offer information without warranty which may be used or disused at own risk. No jurisdictional or medical accountable consultation is given.

8. Legal effectiveness of this exclusion of liability

This exclusion of liability is to be considered as part of the website which has linked to this page. Should parts or formulations of this text not correspond to current law anymore the other parts of the document remain valid. When registering a Twick.it account confirmation of these general terms and conditions (AGB) is obligatory.

item.title: stats
item.dc:creator: markus
item.content:encoded:
URL:

http://twick.it/interfaces/api/stats.xml http://twick.it/interfaces/api/stats.json

Function:

Returns some Twick.it statistics (number of Twicks/topics/users) both for the current language and as the sum over all languages.

Parameters:

Optional/required Values Default Description
lng optional "de", "en" preferred browser language Language for which the statistik should be returned.

Output (XML):

http://twick.it/interfaces/api/stats.xml 
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<result>
  <query>type=xml</query>
  <numberOfTopics>2382</numberOfTopics>
  <numberOfTopicsInLanguage>1857</numberOfTopicsInLanguage>
  <numberOfTwicks>2857</numberOfTwicks>
  <numberOfTwicksInLanguage>2290</numberOfTwicksInLanguage>
  <numberOfUsers>49</numberOfUsers>
  <numberOfUsersInLanguage>28</numberOfUsersInLanguage>
</result>

Output (JSON):

http://twick.it/interfaces/api/stats.json 
{
  query: "type=json"
  numberOfTopics: 2382
  numberOfTopicsInLanguage: 1857
  numberOfTwicks: 2857
  numberOfTwicksInLanguage: 2290
  numberOfUsers: 49
  numberOfUsersInLanguage: 28
}

item.title: random_twick
item.dc:creator: markus
item.content:encoded:
URL:

http://twick.it/interfaces/api/random_twick.xml http://twick.it/interfaces/api/random_twick.json

Function:

Retrieves one or more random Twicks.

Parameters:

Optional/required Values Default Description
limit optional Integer > 0 1 Number of Twicks that should be returned.
username optional String all users Online return Twicks writen by this user.
best optional Boolean 1 or 0 0 Online return Twicks, which are the best rated ones for a topic.
lng optional "de", "en" preferred browser language Language in which should be searched.

item.title: find_user
item.dc:creator: markus
item.content:encoded:
URL:

http://twick.it/interfaces/api/find_user.xml http://twick.it/interfaces/api/find_user.json

Function:

Retrieves data of a specific user.

Parameters:

Optional/required Values Default Description
search required String Username
exact optional Boolean 1 or 0 0 Should the username match exactly (1) or are users returned which username includes the search term as a substring (0)

Output (XML):

http://twick.it/interfaces/api/find_user.xml?search=derlangemarkus 
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<result>

      <country>Deutschland</country>

item.title: The Twick.it story
item.dc:creator: sean
item.content:encoded:
The true story of the explain engine

Soon there will be numerous legends concerning Twick.it – and while Markus and I have no objections to being worshiped – the true story of the explain engine is quite short, simple and a little silly, too.

Colleagues with mutual interests

Markus and I have met in an advertising agency where we both work. As a web developer Markus was dealing a lot with configurators, content management systems and web based applications whereas I as writer, SEO and PR consultant focussed on strategy, conception and text. We quickly discovered our mutual interest in [twickit language="en"]social media[/twickit] such as [twickit language="en"]Twitter[/twickit] and [twickit language="en"]Wikipedia[/twickit]. From the beginning we were fascinated by the possibilities of [twickit language="en"]Web 2.0[/twickit]: Most importantly it allows people to share and spread knowledge – the most important resource of modern times.

Disappointed by Wikipedia, encouraged by Twitter

After trying to participate actively in the German Wikipedia we were quite disappointed by the difficult publishing code and the seemingly unavoidable [twickit language="en"]edit war[/twickit]. Regarding a participatory project the technical barriers as well as the criteria of relevance are far to complex and not up to date. Blogging and Twitter on the other hand are easy, quick and SEO-friendly. Moreover we soon discovered the potential of Twitter as “Wikipedia of news”. We launched a Corporate Blog for our agency, explored [twickit language="en"]WordPress[/twickit] and searched for Twitter applications for the [twickit language="en"]B2B[/twickit] industry.

Birth of Twick.it

The decisive impulse for Twick.it came by chance – in form of an e-mail of another colleague named Frank Schwedes. In this mail Frank asked Markus whether he knew Miki. Miki – mobile Wiki?! Markus didn’t have an idea what it was but it made him start a little buzzword game. What would it sound like to mix Twitter and Wikipedia in one word? What if we combined the best elements of microblogging and encyclopaedia in one application? A social lexicon with entries no longer than a tweet? Twi.ki, Twicker, Twick.it! You could say that Twick.it started of as a typical German “Schnapsidee”. But we got hooked on the idea and quickly developed the concept of Twick.it with the voting system, semantic algorithms and so on.

item.title: Twick.it is not...
item.dc:creator: sean
item.content:encoded:
Twick.it is not a scientific encyclopedia such as Britannica, Wikipedia or Encyclopedia of Life – but an interactive, informative and entertaining explain engine. Twick.it is not a classical search engine like Google, Bing or Evri which uses bots to automatically index the web – but a knowledge data base filled and valuated by humans. Twick.it is not a social network á là Facebook or Linked in. There is no chat function – only the possibility to send direct mails (DM). The networking aspect is secondary and powered by topics. Twick.it is not a microblog such as Twitter where random news can be spread. Instead it is based on a structural encyclopedic basis. Twick.it is not a counsel community such as Ask.com or Yahoo Clever! No questions of individuals are answered. Instead topics are explained in a general way. Twick.it is not a thesaurus such as OpenThesaurus which only explains synonyms, abbreviations and specific terms. Twick.it is not limited to a certain area of topics. Twick.it is not a slang glossary such as UrbanDictionary which collects extraordinary topics. Twick.it is not a bookmarking-tool like Delicious or Mr. Wong where you can collect links on a neutral platform and tag and share them. Twick.it is not a dictionary such as LEO or Dict. But you can compare explanations of topics in different languages. Twick.it is no... cookbook, star forum, photo community, film data base, file sharing host, weapon dictionary, telephone book... Twick.it is what you make of it!

Twick.it combines elements of the things it is not.

Twick.it could be described as a micro blog-encyclopedia in which you can explain specific terms, abbreviations, slang, synonyms and translations, which you can use to bookmark topics and build a topic driven social network. But most importantly the Twick.it search offers short, precise explanations written and valuated by humans.

item.dc:creator: markus

URL:

http://twick.it/interfaces/api/find_topic.xml http://twick.it/interfaces/api/find_topic.json

Function:

Retrieves all topics which includes a given search term. Only the topic's title is searched for the search term not the Twicks.

Parameters:

Optional/required Values Default Description
search required String Search term that should be included in the topic.
limit optional Integer > 0 1 Number of Twicks that should be returned.
lng optional "de", "en" preferred browser language Language in which should be searched

Output(XML):

item.title: Principles
item.dc:creator: sean
item.content:encoded:
1. Knowledge is based on consent.

  2. Sharing knowledge makes sense.

  3. Knowledge is dynamical not set.

  4. A short explanation is often more helpful than an overload of information.

  5. Diversity is better than dogma.

  6. The wisdom of the many produces better explanations than the knowledge of a single expert.

  7. Quality and quantity are no opposites.

  8. There is no “neutral point of view”:

  9. Knowledge is formed by personalities.

  10. Relevance depends on the point of view.

  11. Knowledge can be explained, not edited.

  12. Valuating is more efficient than arguing.

  13. Positive support is more productive than regulation.

  14. Entertaining knowledge attracts more attention and is spread more quickly than pure information.

  15. A good links points to a source with relevant information.

  16. Regarding knowledge “the whole is greater than the sum of its parts.”

  17. The more people join the explain engine the greater is the use for all.

  18. There are more important things that knowledge!

    Family, friends, animals, nature, art, sport... – live.

Knowledge is an exiting expedition – not a crusade. The guidelines listed here are subject to discussion and not a credo carved in stone. The engagement in Twick.it should be fun for everyone and serve the use of the many.

item.title: Twick.it Tool Tip
item.dc:creator: sean
item.content:encoded:
An answer to every question

Who are the [twickit language="en"]Muffin Men[/twickit]? What does [twickit]Hendrix chord[/twickit] stand for? What is the meaning of the abbreviation [twickit language="en"]WWW[/twickit]? Many bloggers and writers use specialist terms and acronyms or cite names their readers have never heard of. They sometimes link to an external website which offers more information. The disadvantage of hyperlinks is obvious though: Some readers will not return to your own website. That’s why we developed the Twick.it Tool Tip. This plug-in allows every webmaster to display 140 character short explanations as tool-tip. Even better: By pressing the alt key and highlighting text the reader can decide himself which words he wants to have explained. Thus [twickit language="en"]TTT[/twickit] can give an answer to every question.

For writers and readers

The Twick.it Tool Tip empowers both writer and reader: The author of an article can define topics which might need explaining. In addition the reader can check on every word of the whole text. This is how it works:
  1. The author marks words with the html-command [ twickit]. TTT searches for the currently best explanation in our database and sets a link. As soon as the reader hovers above the link the tool-tip will be displayed. If the reader clicks on the link he will be forwarded to the equivalent Twick.it topic page.
  2. On every website that installed the Twick.it Tool Tip the reader can mark any word, sentence or list for explanation. All he has to do is hit the alt key and highlight the text segment.
(An article about the installation of our tool-tip is in the making. Please bear with us.)

Future explanations

Webmasters can mark any word with the [ twickit]-command. If the marked word has not been explained at Twick.it yet – nothing will happen. The reader doesn’t notice. As soon as somebody writes a corresponding Twick – the word will be transformed into a link. This function helps your articles stay up to date.

Explaining whole articles

You can use the [ twickitall]-command to find explanations for whole articles. But beware: As our database is growing rapidly your article will be transformed into a confusing hyperlink graveyard. Therefore we would suggest using this function for lists only. Remember: Too much information distracts the reading process. And if you promote the Twick.it Tool Tip to your reader, the [twickitall]-command is superfluous anyway, as....

Highlights are better than hyperlinks

Every webmaster knows this problem: He cannot look into the head of his readers. Even if he could every reader has got individual questions. Look at this simple sentence for example: “John Lennon was the mastermind of The Beatles.” How am I to know which component of this sentence needs to be further explained to a certain reader? Maybe he has never heard of [twickit language="en"]John Lennon[/twickit]. Maybe he spontaneously wants to know the meaning of the first name [twickit language="en"]John[/twickit]. Maybe he is looking for basic information concerning the music group [twickit language="en"]The Beatles[/twickit] or he would like an explanation for the term [twickit language="en"]Mastermind[/twickit]. Whatever question is on your reader’s mind: TTT brings the answer onto the screen – without the need of leaving the browser-window currently opened.

Explaining every word in the web

Twick.it’s Tool Tip functions in every language, in every browser and in every programming code. In theory we can explain every word in the web. It all depends on two factors: Users filling Twick.it with useful content and webmasters integrating and promoting it on their homepages. We believe this can create a win-win situation: The better the Twicks are, the higher is the use of external applications. The more external applications are in use, the greater is the competition and quality control for the best possible explanation.

Download Wordpress plug-in

We have created a plug-in for the blog-software [twickit language="en"]Wordpress[/twickit] which has been tested on several blogs and works fine. You can download it here. Installation is a matter of seconds – and the configuration is quite simple as well.

Feedback welcome

If you are a web developer or blogger and have tried the Twick.it Tool Tip please give us some feedback. Does the standard configuration harmonise with your website? Do you need additional functions or configuration presets? To all fans of [twickit language="en"]Joomla[/twickit] and [twickit language="en"]Typo3[/twickit]: Why don’t you programme a Twick.it Tool Tip yourself? The code couldn’t be any more simple and millions of downloads can’t do your reputation any harm. We would be happy to promote your Twick.it plug-in in our blog, Facebook fan page and Twitter account.

Official information

Unfortunately most of Twick.it's press releases are written in German only. Please have a look at the German blog for a list of all press releases, blog reviews, radio interviews and so on. I am happy to answer all your questions and translate information on request. Simply write an E-Mail to: sean (at) twick.it

item.title: For developers / API
item.dc:creator: markus
item.content:encoded: Developers are welcome. Read more about the API.

item.title: PHP
item.dc:creator: markus
item.content:encoded: PHP developers can access the explanations of Twick.it very easy. We wrote a collection of PHP classes which do all the annoying REST job (send http request, parse XML, etc. for you). The framework is released under BSD licence so you can modify it and you use it for free. Sounds good?! Find more information at sourceforge.net Twick.it-User Sascha Ohms developed a PHP class for the Twick.it API and releases it under Creative Commons licence. Thank you very much. Go to Twick.it API PHP class by Sascha Ohms (german). Surely Sascha is happy about feedback.

item.title: Highlights instead of hyperlinks
item.dc:creator: markus
item.content:encoded: Twick.it offers you an explanation for every possible topic. Simply press the alt key and highlight a text segment. The explanation appears in a speech bubble.

item.title: Wikwik.it – Wikipedia in short
item.dc:creator: sean
item.content:encoded:
Twick.it is the original

When we started Twick.it – we had a vision: to create a collaborative encyclopaedia such as [twickit language="en"]Wikipedia[/twickit] which would be as easy to use and straight to the point as [twickit language="en"]Twitter[/twickit]. This is how we found the name: Twitter + Wikipedia = Twick.it. Of course we researched thoroughly that no similar tool existed in the internet. It was very important for us to create something new and not copy an American model. And that’s the way it is: Twick.it was the first encyclopaedia that applied the principle of preciseness – the strict limitation to the magic 140 characters. Naturally we did not expect to stay the only ones with this idea. For a few months we have been watching a little start-up in Berlin named [twickit language="en"]Wikwik.it[/twickit] which we would like to introduce to you. [caption id="attachment_1044" align="alignnone" width="300" caption="This is Wikwikit"][/caption]

Two names – one concept?

Isn’t it funny how similar the names Twick.it and Wikwik.it are? Both glossaries have an Italian domain and limit the explanations to 140 characters. What’s more: Just like Wikwik.it we started of with the slogan “Straight to the point” before we decided to drop it for the claim “The explain engine” which is easier to remember for a [twickit language="en"]newbie[/twickit]. It’s really curious. If the guys of Wikwik.it weren’t so cute one could easily believe that they have shamelessly copied our whole concept. But wait: if they had copied us they would have also applied more of our functions.

Differences between the micro-encyclopaedias

I don’t want to judge the design – that’s personal taste. There are basic similarities such as a huge search slot and the possibility to create and explain topics. This is very the likeness ends. Wikwik.it offers no semantic tagging; users have to set tags manually. You also have to select a language. Finally an automatic link to Wikipedia is created with every new explanation. These features lead to a series of problems:
  1. Lost: When searching you never know in which language version you are.
  2. Frustrated: The automatic Wikipedia link often leads into nowhere land.
  3. Isolated: It is not possible to set hyperlinks. A solution such as our Tool Tip is not available either.
  4. Mistaken: Apparently the search does not differentiate between tags and search keywords. The manual tagging means more work for the user and offers an open window for vandalism.
Overall my user experience of Wikwik.it was very frustrating. But the worst is yet to come.

Return of the edit wariors

The provocative title of this post is “Wikwik.it – Wikipedia in Short“. But this pinpoints their basic mistake: They have only copied the Wikipedia principle in short – including all the weaknesses. Just as in Wikipedia the users have to find a compromise on one version. Only one version is displayed in the search – and this undoubtedly leads to [twickit language="en"]Edit war[/twickit]. If I don’t like an explanation I can restore an older version with one click. As every [twickit language="en"]Wikipedian[/twickit] knows this will not improve the explanations. In the end the administrator with the longest breath will succeed.

The [twickit language="en"]chicken egg problem[/twickit]

Wikwik.it is still in a closed beta phase. But you can already register to test the service. Ironically the guys at Wikwik.it encounter the same problem as we do. They need to motivate users to generate content – at the same time they need content to improve relevance and motivation for users. Therefore I would like to ask all Twick.it users: Register at Wikwik.it and test it. Have I gone mad to promote our direct competitor? No. We would hate to lose you as user – but your feedback and opinions are most important for us and the further development of Twick.it. In the end only one service will succeed: and that will be decided by you. How do you rate the miniature Wikipedia? What are the advantages or disadvantages of Twick.it in comparison to Wikwik.it? Which name do you prefer? Which function of Wikwik.it would you like to see integrated in the explain engine? You can use our support system for feedback or post a comment. Every opinion counts and will be considered.

item.title: What is an explanation?
item.dc:creator: sean
item.content:encoded:
Definition of explanation

As Twick.it calls itself an [twickit]explain engine[/twickit] – you will expect a convincing answer to the question: “What is an explanation?” I say: An explanation enlightens the listener. It clarifies something by stating the relevant facts. Logical, consistent, sensible – and straight to the point. On the other hand an explanation is interpretation of information directed towards a certain person or group. It relies on context, understanding and existing knowledge of the addressee. Thus every explanation is subject to discussion.

Synonyms for explanation

There are several synonyms for the word explanation: Account, description, reason, justification, rationalization, vindication, clarification, elucidation, explication, definition, enlightenment and so on. This list indicates that facts are central to an explanation. In order to explain something I require secure knowledge – and I have to argue my conclusions coherently. I have to reason. Unfortunately this is where [twickit]objectivity[/twickit] ends.

Whom am I explaining what?

It makes a difference whether I explain a topic such as [twickit]The Beatles[/twickit] to a friend in the pub or to a student of music history. Addressee and context profoundly influence the content of explanations. As you never know who is reading your explanation on Twick.it I suggest: Don’t presume any pre-existing knowledge. Formulate your Twick in a manner that helps somebody who has never heard of the [twickit]Fab Four[/twickit].

What is my intention?

[twickit]Communication[/twickit] is always a social act – even if performed using a neutral platform such as the explain engine. With my explanation I (unconsciously) try to persuade the listener (or reader) of my point of view. Perhaps I want to make an impression with my knowledge or I might be biased. Every explanation is driven by individual [twickit]intention[/twickit]. I need to reflect my intention – otherwise I cannot explain in an objective way. Looking at the Beatles example I have to ask myself: Am I explaining what my childhood heroes mean to me as a fan or do I prefer Heavy Metal and dislike the old stuff?

Reason don’t rate

“The Beatles are the best most popular most successful band in the world.” These statements are not explanations – only opinions. They do not offer any comparable or measurable facts such as dates or statistics. Moreover every personal valuation such as “best” or “bad” requires comparison or understanding of the general context. Therefore valuations, comparatives and superlatives should be handled with care when explaining.

The Five Ws: Who? What? When? Where? Why?

In classical media the [twickit]Five Ws[/twickit] “Who? What? When? Where? Why?” have established themselves as standard for objective documentation. If you answer these five questions you will have covered a great amount of the relevant facts. This also works when you write a Twick. For example you can ask yourself: Who was a member of the Beatles? What kind of music did they produce? Where did they come from? When (during which time) did they record and perform music? Why did they become so successful? Of course not all questions can be answered in 140 characters. So you have to focus on the most important – and choose a good link that offers additional information.

A good explanation:

  • Is constructed on secure information
  • Is sensible and coherent
  • Makes the questioner more clever
By the way: You find an interessting discussion about the nature of explanation at CommonCraft.

What does Wikipedia say?

The first sentence concerning explanation in Wikipedia reads: “An explanation is a set of statements constructed to describe a set of facts which clarifies the causes, context and consequences of those facts.” In short: Statements which describe facts which clarify themselves. Even though the content of this sentence is correct I guess that only very few people can make sense of it. (It certainly took me a long time to understand it.) For a good explanation it is not enough to arrange a couple of keywords, construct a long sentence and sound scientific.

Get to the point

In my opinion an explanation should not be too abstract nor too scientific, neither too general nor too specific, not too difficult to comprehend and not unnecessarily complex. In a nutshell: Avoid all superfluous information, specialist terms and get to the point. Focus on the main topic, be objective and make it as easy for your listener as possible. Especially abstract concepts such as [twickit]love[/twickit], scientific terms such as [twickit]fluidity[/twickit] and stars such as [twickit]Jimi Hendrix[/twickit] are difficult to be defined in 140 characters. That’s the reason we developed the explain engine. It makes use of the stair-principle: Somebody starts – and the next person can build on this foundation and try to formulate a better explanation while the crowd guarantees a fairly objective assessment.

item.title: Webciety CeBIT 2010
item.dc:creator: sean
item.content:encoded:
Twickit presentation on the Webciety stage at CeBIT 2010

Twick.it hit the big stage. At least 150 people were listening to our vision of a universally accessible social glossary which we presented on the [twickit language="en"]Webciety[/twickit] stage at the [twickit language="en"]CeBIT[/twickit]. Not to mention the people watching the lifestream on the internet. After the presentation (which failed spectacularly) we had a professional photo shooting and met Sascha Lobo – Germany’s most famous blogger. By the way: More videos of the CeBIT are available at TwickitTV. After driving through a snow storm for four hours we arrived at the CeBIT in Hannover and prepared the presentation. To make sure nothing could go wrong we installed and opened all the files on the laptop. All the presentation lady had to do was to press the right button. She messed it up, of course. Markus waited on stage for about a minute absolute ages before he could carry on. Luckily I made a backstage documentation of this historic #fail. At least we you have got something to laugh at feel sorry for.

Vision of a social glossary

[caption id="attachment_1165" align="alignright" width="150" caption="Twick.it at Webciety stage CeBIT 2010"][/caption] At least 150 viewers stood in front of the Webciety stage. Markus introduced them to our vision of o collaborative social glossary – which everybody can partake and profit from. Think of a database of short definitions which are accessible in all kinds of electronic media at the push of a button – then you’ve got the idea of the [twickit language="en"]explain engine[/twickit]. To show how it works we had prepared examples of our Tool Tip for the CeBIT website. We also showed how Twick.it could enhance the search results of [twickit language="en"]Wikipedia[/twickit] and even [twickit language="en"]Google[/twickit].

Interview with Sascha Lobo

After our presentation Sascha Lobo talked about his personal highlights of the Webciety. The audience was asked to question Germany’s Mr. Web. As nobody dared I asked whether the dream of Web 3.0 had already come to an end. Sascha answered that not many people have yet understood the difference between [twickit language="en"]Web 2.0[/twickit] and the new buzzword [twickit language="en"]Web 3.0[/twickit]. Moreover these words have been substituted by a new hype [twickit language="en"]Social Media[/twickit]. Afterwards we briefly talked to Sascha Lobo before he had to go to his own photo shoot. He has promised though to answer our questions on the future of the semantic web and social media via e-mail. Markus and I would like to thank all Twick.it-Fans who encouraged us live, via Twitter and SMS. When the presentation failed the Twitterwall was displayed on the big screen. You could see a tweet of Billomat. His message “Go, Twick.it go“ is my most memorable moment of the Webciety.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Were the 150 people in a queue, as in "a list", one behind the other, or were they listening, as in hearing, to your presentation? Surely the first sentence should read: "At least 150 people were LISTENING to our vision ... "

item.title: Twitter
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Twick.it has got various [twickit language="en"]Twitter[/twickit] accounts to supply you with news and random explanations:

@twickit

Here the Twick.it team twitters news about the explain engine.

@twickit_api

News for progammers that use the Twick.it-API.

@twickit_de

Must-read for smart-asses. This account randomly twitters the best German explanations.

@twickit_en

So you're a wisenheimer? Then follow this account for random explanations in English language.

@twickit_podcast

Twitters new posts from the Twick.it podcast where Twicks are read (German only).

@twickit_fame

We would like to thank you. If you wrote a lot of Twicks, we will praise you. Fully automatic but warm ;-)

@SeanKollak

Sean Kollak twitters in German and English about Social Media and Web 2.0

@derlangemarkus

Markus Möller twitters in German about ... everything.

item.title: find_topics_nearby
item.dc:creator: markus
item.content:encoded:
URL:

http://twick.it/interfaces/api/find_topics_nearby.xml http://twick.it/interfaces/api/find_topics_nearby.json

Function:

Retrieves all topics that are located nearby a position, which is specitied by a geo coordinate (latitude and longitude). The distance between the given position an the position of he topic is return at the tag called distance.

Parameters:

optional/required Values Default Description
latitude required Gleitkommazahl [twickit]Breitengrad[/twickit] im Gradmaß. Positive Werte bedeuten Norden, negative Werte Süden.
longitude required Gleitkommazahl [twickit]Längengrad[/twickit] im Gradmaß. Positive Werte bedeuten Osten, negative Werte Westen.
radius optional Ganzzahlen > 0 10000 Der Radius in Metern, in dem gesucht werden soll.
limit optional Ganzzahlen > 0 250 Die Anzahl der Twicks, die zurückgegeben werden sollen.
lng optional "de", "en" Sprache des Browsers Sprache, in der gesucht werden soll.

http://twick.it/interfaces/api/find_topics_nearby.xml?latitude=50.875556&longitude=8.016667&radius=15000&limit=2

item.title: find_twicks_from_user
item.dc:creator: markus
item.content:encoded:
URL:

http://twick.it/interfaces/api/find_twicks_from_user.xml http://twick.it/interfaces/api/find_twicks_from_user.json

Function:

Retrieves all Twicks written by a specific user.

Parameters:

Optional/required Values Default Description
search required String The username.
limit optional Integer > 0 unlimited Number of Twicks that should be returned.
lng optional "de", "en" preferred browser language Language in which should be searched.

Output (XML):

item.title: Twickit wins international Augmented Reality Championship and German Social Media Prize
item.dc:creator: sean
item.content:encoded:
2010 has been quite amazing for Twick.it.: The explain engine won an international augmented reality competition, earned second place in the German Social Media Prize and launched a podcast for definitions under Creative Commons licence in cooperation with the German Wikimedia foundation. Here you can find links to the official announcements. If you need further information feel free to contact me.

Wikitude Augmented Reality Worldcup

[caption id="" align="alignright" width="150" caption="Wikitude Worldcup Winner 2010"][/caption] On 18th of August 2010 Wikitude announced the winners of the international Augmented Reality Worldcup. The best applications for the augmented reality browser of Wikitude were awarded. Twick.it won in the category "Social" in spite of strong competition by internationally established services such [twickit]Gowalla[/twickit] and [twickit]Sagis[/twickit].

Social Media Prize 2010 by Twittwoch e.V.

[caption id="attachment_1347" align="alignright" width="150" caption="German Social Media Prize"][/caption] On the 10th November 2010 Twittwoch e.V. named the winners of the German Social Media Prize 2010. More than 15.000 people voted by e-mail in the final round. Twick.it won the second place in the category "society".

Podcast for Free Knowledge

Since the 1st of February 2011 Twick.it offers a podcast with spoken definitions. The podcast is realized in cooperation with Tabitha Hammer who has won the WissensWert competition of Wikimedia Deutschland e.V. The spoken definitions which have a Creative Commons licence can also be received at iTunes.

item.title: New community functions for better communication
item.dc:creator: sean
item.content:encoded:
In July 2011 we have introduced three major new functions to improve the communication between the users of the explain engine. From now on: [caption id="attachment_1359" align="alignright" width="150" caption="Have your say"][/caption]
  1. You can leave public messages in each other’s “Speakers’ corner” to start a group discussion.
  2. You can write private messages using “Chinese whispers”.
  3. You can configure your own automatic notifications with the “Radar”.
In addition you can use this blog, the support system, or our social media channels such as Facebook, Twitter, Youtube as well as numerous RSS feeds for feedback and information.

How do Speakers’ corner, Chinese whispers and the radar work?

1. Speakers` corner for public discussion

Every user has an individual Speakers` corner which is made up of the public entries of other users and your own answers. This is the equivalent of the timeline you know from Facebook or the [twickit]discussion page[/twickit] at Wikipedia. A long time ago this used to be called a [twickit word="guestbook (web)"]guestbook[/twickit]. You may use the Speakers’ corner to praise, criticise or correct other users. To make appointments for group action and to ask for additional information. Don’t be shy to use it: All your public messages can be deleted again by yourself at any time.

2. Chinese whispers for private messages

Some things should stay private. If a message is only intended for a single user Chinese Whispers is the appropriate medium. Advice: As soon as you have new whispers in your inbox a red symbol lights up at the top frame – reading “You have X messages.” If you click on this your message centre opens. By the way: You can comment directly on any explanation while reading it. Simply click on the little envelope symbol in the bottom right corner of the speech bubble. Then you decide weather to write a public or private message. The link to the explanation you are referring to is automatically inserted in your message.

3. Radar for individual notifications

With the radar you will never miss an update on a topic that is important to you. You can be notified when one of your explanations has been voted up or down. You can be notified when another user writes an explanation for a topic you have already explained. And you can add specific users to your radar you share mutual interests with. The radar can be used to control specific users but also makes collaborative work on specialist topics easier. (More radar notifications are already in the pipeline.)

You simply want some peace?

No problem. You can alter every setting for Speakers’ corner, Chinese whispers and radar at any time – or simply deactivate them all. By this means you can focus on explaining topics in 140 characters without any community exchange. Love to hear what you think of the new community functions.
